captions.text: Hello Internet,

Enjoying your Internetting session? Perhaps
watching this video with lots of tabs open

and full of interesting things to check out.
The Internet is amazing and that's because

of the rules which govern how it works, an
important one of which is Net Neutrality:
treating all data equally.

But some Internet Providers want to ditch
this rule to insert themselves betwixt you

and your data as the most meddlesome middlemen
in human history -- to their benefit and our
detriment.

How? Well think of the Internet as a series
of pipes. Some are ocean-and-continent spanning
pipes through which vast rivers of data flow.

You don't get access to those -- they're very
expensive, and you couldn't handle it anyway.

But you do have a little pipe that connects
to the big pipes, through which you can pull

down and send out data. Your pay your Internet
provider to maintain this pipe.

This rule means that your little pipe, cares
not what flows through it: cat videos, discussion

forums, calls or games. Whatever you're doing,
you're using the whole pipe to do and no website
gets preference over another.

Everyone wants faster Internet, but that requires
more metaphorical pipe in the ground, the
building of which is slow and expensive.

Now you may have heard your Internet provider
on the news talking about how this rule prevents

them from building 'fast lanes' for special
kinds of data -- they want you to think they're

expanding your access to the information superhighway.
But removing this rule also gives them the

power to speedbump the existing roads and
charge more to use the 'fast' lane that was
just what you had before.

The power to preference some data over others
is the power to favor one video site over

another and to limit a tiny part of the pipe
for the video you're watching right now or
trying to anyway.

We've been through this before: and constrain
other companies in similar ways. Take the

electricity. You pay for a certain amount
and when it arrives in your house you can

do with it what you wish. The electricity
company doesn't get to decide that rather

than build more power plants it's going to
dim your bulbs and then offer a 'brighter

bulbs' monthly subscription. And so it should
go with the Internet. Watts are watts and

bits are bits and we'll always need more and
more.

And preserving this rule for the Internet
has much wider impact than just if some company

takes more of your coins. Not to be overly
dramatic here, but preserving data equality

may be one of the most important issues in
a generation. Because without this rule Internet

providers could cripple competitors they don't
like.

Ever notice the same company that sells you
internet also sells Cable TV and Landlines

-- stuff The Internet totally replaces? Without
data equality your Internet Provider could

narrow the pipe for competitors until they
either go out of business, pay the meddlesome
middleman, or both.

It's like if one store in town super-promised
to pay for fast roads everywhere as long as

the town gave them absolute power over all
the roads no backsies. If you agree to that

deal don't be surprised when years later all
traffic to them is fast and free while the
roads elsewhere are slow and neglected.

This town is basically the Internet without
net neutrality which some Internet Providers

would love, but actual Internet citizens,
not so much.

Having the pipes treat all data the same lets
one guy with a good idea and a bit of programming

knowledge make something today that's seen
by millions tomorrow. But only because his

data is treated equally with everything else
in the pipes.

An Internet that treats data equally is an
internet that continues to shower us with

wonder. But an Internet where middlemen pick
and choose what comes through the pipe is

an Internet of stagnation for all and profit
for few. Which is why some Internet providers

will always want that control, so the cost
of preserving our awesome Internet is eternal

vigilance on the part of good citizens to
defend Net Neutrality.

comments.text:
i think the issue is that the government is using the concept of net 
neutrality as a means to finagle their way into controlling/regulating the 
internet. Yes they will keep it "neutral" but it will give the FCC access 
to regulations, and you and i both know that giving anyone any control over 
something as powerful as the internet will inevitably result in their 
corruption. To give anyone the power to say they can't do something, no 
matter the scale of it, is a bad thing. Im for net neutrality, im against 
having the FCC be the ones to regulate it. With that being said, i have to 
ask, where does the FCC get the authority to regulate it in the first 
place? Yes it was invented by DARPA, but public ISPs made it accessible to 
everyone. The Supreme Courts ruled against the FCCs ability to regulate it 
in 2010 because basically, they wouldve established sketchy legal 
foundations. Why, 5 years later, would their intentions be any different. 
"oh we really care about the peoples access to the internet, and dont worry 
about this bill that we wont make public until after it passes, we promise 
our intentions are pure" Yeah right﻿

comments.author: benjamin Rhodes (woola1234)

comments.text:
Actually, the FCC has every intention of accelerating the decay of existing 
infrastructure. Considered "natural monopolies", existing government 
regulations restrict the ability of startups to provide competitive 
services. The FCC's Net Neutrality does not address this aspect in any way. 
What will happen is that, just like with electrical utilities, there will 
be absolutely no incentive to upgrade beyond an increase in population. So 
we'll all get the same terrible service forever from the same companies, 
and we'll pay more for the privilege. But hey, at least we're all in it 
together.

Or, we could stop labeling ISPs as "natural monopolies" and cut the hurdles 
for innovation and competition. This would allow new providers to promise 
equally faster speeds for everybody, at a lower cost (hey, maybe the new 
guys make less overall, but it's enough to grow their business - this is 
called entrepreneurship) and pants-kick the dusty old ISPs into "moving it 
or losing it". See, the government has a tendency to create problems 
through regulation. But we're stupid for thinking new, additional, 
regulations are going to fix a problem they don't actually address.﻿

comments.text:
+Dustin Thornton My view was not narrow.  You also made an assertion about 
the privatization of water in the rd world that I know from experience is 
false.  The really bad water suppliers were the private ones.  The reason I 
used those places as examples was specifically because the private systems 
were examples of very bad systems.

You also made the claim that large scale corruption can only happen with 
the support of government.  This is very simply false.  It is one of those 
generalizations that gets used to try to blame government for things they 
didn't do.


At this point we are way off the net neutrality topic.
comments.author: Ken Smith

comments.text:
+Ken Smith
That is such an extremely narrow view, I don't know where to begin. First 
of all, there's Sandy Springs, Georgia (on the private side), so you've 
wrong on the "always worse" point. There's also the example of the 
developing world, where water privatization is leading to cleaner, more 
reliable, and cheaper access to public utilities, especially water. If you 
are honestly pointing to Enron as an example of unbridled private action, 
well, you don't understand that story. That story involves a level of 
corruption that can only be sustained by government intervention.
comments.author: Dustin Thornton

comments.text:
+Dustin Thornton
The FCC classification as common carrier makes protectionism less likely on 
the internet. 

I have been to places without utilities like water, sewer, gas, electricity 
etc.  I have seen that situation.  I have also seen the situation with 
utilities.  I much prefer what I have seen with utilities over what  saw 
without them.  People like to whine and grumble about utilities but when 
you turn on the tap the water that comes out is clean and costs you a lot 
less than others pay for water.  The gas mains have provided you with 
extremely reliable energy at quite a low price per Joule.  If you want to 
compare private with public utilities, look at places that have privatized 
public utilities.  The results are always worse than the public case.  Look 
back the era of Enron for a US case.  Look at rail etc in the UK for others
comments.author: Ken Smith

comments.text:
It was January 2014 - I'm aware. And I do honestly have hopes the new 
ruling will do some good (but that is in no way my expectation; what I 
expect is a new era of protectionism), but I'm saying it's coming from the 
wrong direction. Are you happy with your electricity company? Your phone 
company? Your gas company?
comments.author: Dustin Thornton

comments.text:
+Dustin Thornton
Are you unaware of the supreme courts ruling of spring 2014 on the matter?

Before the ruling the ISPs could not force some data onto the slow lane.  
They could not disfavor their competitors data flowing through their 
network.  With the court ruling this became allowed.  The wording of the 
supreme courts ruling basically directed the FCC to reclassify the ISPs if 
they wanted to have rules like that.  The reclassification happened and we 
are now back to a neutral internet with one other change that would make it 
easier for a new ISP to start.  Since the ISP is now a common carrier, they 
are no longer liable for that which passes through there systems.  Thus 
there is no risk of law suit over data that only went through.  A small ISP 
generally does not have its own content.  A big ISP generally does have its 
own content.  Thus the big ISP have a lot more legal worries.
comments.author: Ken Smith

comments.text:
+Ken Smith
Exactly what changed that we are "going back" to? And how does the ruling 
make starting an ISP easier?
comments.author: Dustin Thornton

comments.text:
You said "believe me" in a statement that  is clearly wrong.  The new 
ruling does not make it harder to start a new ISP.  All the current ISPs 
got started before spring of 2014.  Going back to net neutrality if 
anything makes it easier t start a new ISP.
comments.author: Ken Smith

comments.text:
+Ken Smith
Although it does cost a fortune to lay fiber, investors are often driven 
away because profit takes so long to happen. That process is notoriously 
prolonged by frivolous lawsuits by the largest ISPs. Believe me, Comcast is 
as happy as anyone about the FCC's ruling. Maybe they're rankling about how 
they'll even out speeds, but they're being protected from competition by 
huge new hurdles.
comments.author: Dustin Thornton

comments.text:
The only way to cut the hurdles would be for a government program to run 
new infrastructure from the backbone to the users.  The cost of the 
infrastructure is the hurdle not the regulations.  We had net neutrality 
right up until the court ruled in spring of 2014.  The high speed network 
you use today was created under those rules.

comments.author: Thanatos Destrudo

comments.text:
One thing to keep in mind - not only internet goes through your pipe. For 
example: you have a DSL connection with a physical limit of 10Mbits per 
second. If you use an IP phone and a IPTV over that same DSL connection - 
that is not using the internet, it is a local network. You get 2 Mbits 
reserved for TV an phone and are paying for 8Mbits of the internet. That is 
GOOD! It is not portable however, only works in your house for your 
subscription.

This means that allthough the NET neutrality is respected, you can still 
have the "fast lanes" for IP services, but not over the internet (public 
network).

However, if your ISP is providing you with a VoIP through the internet 
(public network, your 8Mbits), then they should not be able to favor their 
Application traffic.

So dont let ISPs fool you. Defend the NET Neutrality!

ISPs can make different competitive decisions (such as - not charging 
cellular data for their private video or email service). Thats has nothing 
to do with the quality of service, but it benefits you for paying less.﻿

comments.author: Nabila Iqbal

comments.text:
You now, there's a part of this debate that I think is not mentioned 
enough.  

In the 1990s was my birthplace on the Internet.  I got a WebTV from my 
parents for Christmas in december of 1997.  Do you know what speed I ran at?

0.03 megs (i.e. 28.8k modem).  Now, even with 28.8k modems, did that stifle 
innovation in any way?  Did people say "gollie gee, we're too slow, we 
can't invent!"  No, of course not.

The speed of the Internet is NOT the primary factor that drives innovation 
over the Internet.  So, let's assume that ISPs do use fast lanes:  So what? 
 

There are ways to get around it first of all, and secondly, it does not 
stifle innovation.

You know what DOES stifle innovation and has been shown to do it over and 
over again?  Government interference, that's right.  By changing the 
Internet as radically as Title II does, you are discouraging the fast-paced 
advancement of network services.  Know all of that innovation we've had 
over the last couple decades?  Title II had nothing to do with it, and it's 
going to stop it.

Stating that the Internet should be operated like a utility is like saying 
that we should never progress, never innovate, just keep all of our speeds 
the exact same for all time because this is good enough.

Other countries don't see things the same way.

And you know what?  You think that this even gets to go to a vote?  Do you 
think the American people have ONE bit of say in this?  Of course not.  The 
FCC is an unelected body full of lobbyists of the very same companies that 
want Title II regulation.  FCC officials aren't elected based on their 
performance, but based on how much money they fork over to get the benefit 
of working for other bureaucrats.

That's how bureaucrats are selected.

This is what they want.  They want no competition because of excessive and 
potentially unlimited regulations.﻿
comments.author: Global Warming Skeptic

comments.text:
The government will end up being no better than corporations.  If you think 
that fast lanes are bad, just wait until you see what nasty things the 
government can do with your data access.  We already saw it with SOPA and 
PIPA attempts years back.  

THAT is the future.  In addition, with the FCC regulating the Internet, we 
can see yet more rules applying to the Internet soon.

This idea that government knows what's best for the Internet is just 
incorrect.  

It's amazing how minds change when people are threatened with fear 
mongering such as claiming the ISPs are going to slow down all competition. 
 They've been able to do this for 20 years now.  If they wanted to do it, 
they would have already done so.  ﻿
comments.author: Global Warming Skeptic

comments.text:
Curiously, your fantastic Mario Pipe analogy never has the other side of 
the pipe. THIS is where Net Neutrality is a problem, not the little modem 
in some dark corner of your house. Oh, well, you have it now ... let's see 
how the next few years go ...﻿
comments.author: Zack Sargent

comments.text:
I have a libertarian "all regulations are evil" buddy that I convinced to 
support net neutrality pretty easily.  The year:  1995.  Barnes and Noble 
notices a little dip in their sales that they didn't predict.  They do some 
research, and find out that there's some upstart bookseller on this 
"internet" thing that's becoming popular, and it's taking business from 
them.  They contact the top ten internet service providers and say "We'll 
pay you to not let people go to this website."   The internet bookseller 
finds out about this blacklist, and goes to the ISPs and says "We'll pay 
you more so people can go to our website!"  But, alas, Barnes and Noble had 
more money.  And thus, Amazon.Com closes down, because they can't maintain 
profitability from the small percentage of customers who can still access 
their website.

Net Neutrality supports the free market.﻿
comments.author: astramancer

comments.text:
How do we stop the FCC from doing the same thing we don't want ISP's doing? 
 We can't apply the logic of "These people are doing bad things" to one 
half of the coin without also applying it to the other.

I agree, a company should not have the power to cripple their service to 
another person or business, and then charge more to provide what they were 
supposed to be providing in the first place, especially in the case of 
ISP's, which are nearly Monopolies.  However, I also don't want an 
inefficient government agency to have control over the greatest free-speech 
vehicle ever.

So how do we compromise?  How do we protect ourselves (The internet 
citizens) from the group that's trying to protect us?﻿

oh dear, you got the name mixed up.  the "net neutrality" bill (which I

and organizations after nice sounding stuff so that people who don't 
research the topic will vote for it or feel ok if the law was passed.

comments.text:
Everyone is going to get screwed with net neutrality, everyone's service is 
going to slow, and become far more expensive. Giving the government the 
power to regulate the internet is not a good thing does anyone think that 
giving the government the power to regulate the net to be a good thing? 
Just look what Obama was able to accomplish with the IRS he used the IRS to 
prevent conservative groups from obtaining tax free status. the fact is if 
they have to expand the bandwidth, that money has to come from those who 
pay for their services, i.e you and me and everyone currently paying for 
internet services, second if they are forced to provide the same services 
to everyone then they will have to charge everyone the same price. meaning 
those currently paying a premium price will no longer pay a premium price 
given that doing so will not provide them with better service, and to make 
up for the loss of all those paying a premium price everyone will be forced 
to pay a higher price for their services. Example say you have 10 paying 
for internet service. 5 pay $50/month 3 pay $200/month and 2 pay $500/month 
so $1850 total between the 10 people so for everyone to receive and equal 
amount of service each person would have to pay $185 per month while the 
top 5 would receive less band with. Now to increase the number of lanes you 
would have to raise that now $185/month per person even higher to cover the 
cost of the new increased bandwidth, either through upgrades of servers, 
routers, or physical lines such as cable or fiber optic.  ﻿

comments.text:
The biggest issue I have with Net Neutrality is that ISPs have had the 
power to do these malicious deeds for years but never have, and they're not 
going to start now. Furthermore, I for one don't want my internet treated 
equally. If I'm watching Netflix while someone in the other room is surfing 
a website, they won't mind if it takes a little longer for the page to 
load. I, however, would mind if the movie takes a few moments to buffer 
every few minutes. Net neutrality would be eradicating a non-existent issue 
and creating a new one. Plus, since when was more laws and more government 
power a good thing?﻿

don't see much issue in being weary of the government. It's more 
complicated than this, but you can think of a scale that goes from anarchy 
to socialism, sliding from less government to more. The more power the 
government gets, the closer we move to the end of that spectrum. Right now 
we're in the middle, and I don't want to move one way or the other. I'm not 
saying that more government power would be the end of days, but I can't see 
how it would be an improvement.

comments.author: Zealiance

comments.text:
Does anyone understand the technical implications of this policy? You know 
what no broadband management means? No more traffic 
shaping/differentiation, no more QoS! Net Neutrality will create a "dumb" 
network that does not differentiate data or inspect it, and just forwards 
it. This will not be redundant, or fault tolerant. When something goes 
wrong, the solution will be to just put in a bigger pipe, which will be 
paid for by taxpayers. When you strip management from broadband providers 
and treat them like public utilities, you destroy every reason for them to 
innovate. ﻿
comments.author: Brooks Olney

comments.text:
Net Neutrality is pretty much what we have now, and it is working well. I 
can view Netflix, Hulu Plus, Comcast Xfinity, Amazon instant video, and use 
ATT website at all the same speed, even though they are all competitors. 
Without net Neutrality, my Netflix could possibly be slower because my 
internet is operated by a competitor of Netflix. The internet isn't run by 
the government or tax payers. The laws past recently just say that all data 
must be treated equally, because no one knows if someone's little  idea on 
Reddit will become the next big thing, so it better load just as fast as 
FOX news.

people have, they'll fuck us over. There is no competition. Unless I move 
to a different part of the country I have to put up with whatever BS 
comcast decides to shovel at me.

And rather than creating a new post, I can't just stop using the internet. 
I'm in college and while we have an excellent library it is undeniable that 
the internet has far more information than the library does. When it comes 
time for me to wirte a research paper, I can either hit the books and in 
some cases find about 5 books from 1980 - present with info that may not 
even be relevant, or I can go on the internet and find scholarly sources 
written yesterday by esteemed individuals. Or, you know, maybe I could just 
boycott the internet and hope that everyone else does too and compromise my 
overpriced education in the process.

comments.author: Thurston Pilgrim

comments.text:
+Pretentious Pedantic Prick
An important point is that the internet has become very like a public 
market place.  Buyers and sellers gather in this virtual market place.  In 
a physical market place, one seller is not allowed to block access to their 
rivals. When this was done in physical market places economies thrived.  
When the same rule applies to the virtual market place, the economy 
thrives.  The motives don't matter to the results.  Thus even if making the 
ISPs common carrier was done with the worst motive in the world, its result 
is still a thriving economy.
comments.author: Ken Smith

comments.text:
+JakesyDude While that is true, that doesn't change the fact that the 
actual law that was recently passed enforcing net neutrality allows the 
government to regulate the internet as it pleases similar to how ISPs 
were/would have been allowed to. The difference is the simple fact that the 
government doesn't hold direct control over the internet like an ISP does. 
If the feds, states, or even counties and towns wanted to slow down or 
outright censor certain websites the ISP stands as a middle man to that and 
it should be common knowledge by now that large corporations, especially 
those with pseudo monopolies like most ISPs, are the ones who pay the 
government to do their bidding not the other way around. At this point the 
government directly fucking with the internet isn't a matter of if they 
legally can, should, or would want to, it's the simple fact the government 
can't afford to. Net neutrality as a concept is inherently consumer 
friendly, but what was recently put into practice is consumer friendly by 
consequence. 

tl;dr the government very obviously tried to get another way to control the 
people but didn't realize that they put a very expensive middle man "upset" 
with their decisions to pass a law inbetween them and the assumption of 
direct control.
comments.author: Pretentious Pedantic Prick

comments.text:
+Thurston Pilgrim net neutrality isn't as much a regulation on the internet 
as it is a regulation on what corporations can do with access to it. Its a 
regulation to prevent regulation.

comments.author: Paul Mike

comments.text:
I would like to think I am authority on this subject since I have been 
constructing a 20 page thesis regarding Net Neutrality for the past year. I 
came from your point of view when I started, but I have since realized what 
Net Neutrality has become. There are many more facets to Net Neutrality 
than just discrimination against certain types of data. We have to consider 
many other things such as last mile infrastructure, privacy issues (In 
regards to 3rd party ISPs selling info about their customers), Tom 
Wheeler's background in the cable industry, President Obama influencing an 
independent federal agency, how the new Open Internet Order overrides some 
laws in various states (Violation of Tenth Amendment), how the FCC passed 
the new order without transparency, and many more. There's more baggage to 
Net Neutrality than you think. Also, I had Verizon for 2 years and it 
sucked, I'm talking 2mb/s down and 300 ms latency suck. I've had bad 
Internet, and I literally could not watch videos at 240p.  However, it was 
a small local WISP that started servicing my area, breaking Verizon's 
monopolistic hold in my neighborhood. Since then that WISP has taken nearly 
all of Verizon's customers in our area and I can watch 1080p video with a 
4mb/s down and 20ms latency connection now. Let the free market do its job.
comments.author: Zach Day

comments.text:
+Zach Day What the fuck do you even think the new law is about? All it does 
is prevent restriction to accessing content, what about not being able to 
watch netflix in decent speeds depending on your Provider is "innovative" 
to you?
comments.author: GuiltyMiner0343

comments.text:
It's those corporate companies that pay the people's paycheck and then it's 
the government that takes 40% of it away. Don't value the government too 
high and don't underestimate the free market. For example, look at 
T-Mobile. They went from the verge of death to actually being relevant by 
doing innovative things like Music Freedom. The new Open Internet Order 
voted in by the FCC threatens innovations like that. Sure, Music Freedom 
only applies to certain music streaming applications. But they have 18 of 
the most popular options. Not to mention, music streaming providers can 
apply to be added to T-Mobile's program and T-Mobile's customers can vote 
to add new ones. If a music streaming program isn't under Music Freedom, 
it's because the consumer doesn't want it. Therefore, the program does not 
really discriminate against any company or type of data. All this to say is 
that the government is a threat to these innovations made by smaller 
companies. Let the free market work on its own. I like the idea of Net 
Neutrality, but I don't want the FCC, an independent federal agency, to 
make laws that affect me and I don't get a say in it. I'd rather have Net 
Neutrality regulation passed through Congress that recognizes our free 
market Capitalist system.
comments.author: Zach Day

comments.text:
+Paul Mike It's lesser of two evils.
Government Control with only POTENTIAL bad side effects is way better than 
Corporate-run internet with GUARANTEED bad side effects.
comments.author: BitchSan

comments.text: how do you know? did u read the bill? you ppl are SHEEP
comments.author: Paul Mike

comments.text:
Good thing it won't be government run then huh?  Also, everything else you 
said was wrong.
comments.author: TheyCallMeNerdBoy

comments.text:
I smell bullshit here. What "rule" is this guy even talk about? The 
internet is a series of protocols which define how it works and no where is 
it written that all data must serviced equally. ISP's could limit output 
now or any time in the past but they *haven't* because they value not 
pissing off customers and surviving to live another day. This is just a 
trojan horse for the government to regulate the internet so beware.﻿
comments.author: Hairy Pixels

comments.text:
Net neutrality is for the internet what the DMV is for vehicles. You set it 
in motion and it stays the same as the bureaucrats with power, not 
knowledge or foresight, set the standards. Imagine if they took it over in 
1995. We'd all be on dial up with the AOL monopoly chopping up 56k so we 
could each download a picture a day "fairly".﻿
comments.author: Lukeor

comments.text:
+Guillermo Gonzalez the internet in the first decade of this millennium has 
become much more dominated by a few players then it was in the last decade 
of the last millennium.
comments.author: Isaac Karjala

comments.text:
+haltopen12 there is no evidence that Comcast throttled Netflix, all 
evidence points to a peering issue between Comcast and Level 3. These 
peering issues have arisen repetitively throughout the history of the 
internet and they've gotten resolved without state intervention. And really 
name one industry that is regulated by the FCC that isn't dominated by an 
extremely limited number of players, but hey let's give them another chance.

"Blah blah blah, this is just making ISPs common carriers blah blah blah, 
it won't result in Comcast becoming more of a monopoly then they are 
already"

It also won't do jack shit to fix the problem since common carrier has no 
QoS guarantees so nothing to force Comcast to expand there connectivity to 
Level 3.
comments.author: Isaac Karjala

comments.text:
Thankfully, idiots like you are mostly ignored. The Net Neutrality rules 
have been in place since the early 2000s and, until Obama put his 2 cents 
in, I hadn't heard people like you complaining about those rules. So under 
the very same rules that you say will hobble the internet, somehow it has 
grown to where it is today. I don't think you're using a dial up connection 
and neither am I, so why didn't your internet doomsday become a reality 
this whole time?
comments.author: Guillermo Gonzalez

comments.text:
Then its a good thing they aren't taking over the internet. Net Neutrality, 
contrary to the opinions of idiots, is not about the government regulating 
the internet. Its about the government preventing Internet Service 
Providers from fucking with consumers internet access.

comments.author: blarg minton

comments.text:
If you like net neutrality, then subscribe to an ISP that is net neutral. 
Asking the government to regulate internet companies (and thereby extending 
it's powers over the internet) is a disaster waiting to happen. I like net 
neutrality, and I like it that people are spreading awareness about it 
which will naturally force ISPs to rethink their strategies. 

However the dangerous slippery slope is to ask the government to intervene 
which will give the government the powers and the authority over ISPs 
(which in turn means a police state)﻿
comments.author: Ezio17a

comments.text: good
comments.author: Ezio17a

comments.text: I have signed petitions and campaigned locally for GF.
comments.author: Scott S.

comments.text:
Actually just by creating awareness, you have created a threat to these 
companies. If Google fiber takes hold and is net neutral while these 
companies are not, then most people will jump ship to google destroying 
these companies.

Asking the government to regulate ISPs is much much worse, basically you 
are handing out government the power over the internet. 

And while it's much easier to choose between companies - it's not exactly 
easier to get politicians elected who would rescind government's control 
over the internet, once granted.
comments.author: Ezio17a

comments.text:
Haha Sure, the choice is ATT or Comast, take it or leave it, so there is no 
choice.
comments.author: Scott S.

comments.text:
I completely agree with this video on the fact that information should 
remain equal and unrestrained to all; I disagree with the use of net 
neutrality to insure that. All net neutrality does is get the government 
involved with an otherwise reasonable and legitimate system that has worked 
for a while. Adding government to the mix will restrain the internet MORE, 
not free it up as this video (and much of the internet) suggests. If an 
internet company did add these "fastlanes" or whatever, a good competitive 
environment would make these harmful by discouraging customers to use their 
service.﻿
